elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Observed (dots) and calculated (line) X-ray powder diffraction patterns for (a) [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), and (b) [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Ni(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Miller indices are indicated only for the first few diffraction peaks.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Observed (dots) and calculated (line) X-ray powder diffraction patterns for (a) [Fe(abpt)2(Pt(CN)4)] (1), and (b) [Fe(abpt)2(Ni(CN)4)] (2). Miller indices are indicated only for the first few diffraction peaks.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Ortep <ce:cross-ref id="c0175" refid="b0075">[15]</ce:cross-ref> plot of the 1-D neutral structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 294<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K showing the asymmetric unit, the atom labeling scheme and the metal ion environment. Codes of equivalent positions: (i) −x, −y, −z; (ii) −x<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −y, −z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  Ortep [15] plot of the 1-D neutral structure of 1 at 294K showing the asymmetric unit, the atom labeling scheme and the metal ion environment. Codes of equivalent positions: (i) -x, -y, -z; (ii) -x-1, -y, -z+1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Projection view of the overall molecular structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> showing the 1-D bimetallic coordination polymer and the inter-chain abpt π–π stacking.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Projection view of the overall molecular structure of 1 showing the 1-D bimetallic coordination polymer and the inter-chain abpt π-π stacking.

<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0020">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Thermal variation of the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> product in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Inset shows the thermal variation of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>. Second inset shows the thermal variation of <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>

<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>)/<ce:italic>δT</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Thermal variation of the χ m T product in 1. Inset shows the thermal variation of χ m. Second inset shows the thermal variation of δ(χ m T)/δT.

<ce:label>Scheme 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0025">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">Intermolecular π-stacking of the abpt ligands in the Fe-abpt systems: (a) frontal π-stacking; (b) sideways π-stacking.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Scheme 1  Intermolecular π-stacking of the abpt ligands in the Fe-abpt systems: (a) frontal π-stacking; (b) sideways π-stacking.

Two iron(II) coordination neutral chain of formula [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)] (M=PtII and NiII) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Both compounds exhibit SCO transition transitions above room temperature.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

New iron(II) coordination polymeric neutral chain of formula [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)], with M=PtII (1), NiII (2) and abpt=4-amino-3,5-bis(pyridin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole, have been synthesized and characterized by infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. The two compounds are isostructural as deduced from a Rietveld analysis of X-ray powder diffraction data of 2 simulated from the single crystal structure of 1. The crystal packing of 1 is formed by regular chains running along the crystallographic [-101] direction where the planar [Pt(CN)4]2- anion acts as a μ2-bridging ligand via two nitrogen atoms of two different trans cyano groups, while the two abpt molecules act as chelating ligands. Along the neutral chains, the Fe⋯Pt distances are imposed by the cyano groups of the [Pt(CN)4]2- moiety (5.027 and 5.022Å at 294 and 150K, respectively), leading to Fe⋯Fe intrachain distances of 10.055 and 10.045Å at 294 and 150K, respectively. The thermal dependence of the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility times the temperature (χ m T) for compound 1 shows a constant value close to 0.2emuKmol-1 in the temperature range 10-300K in the cooling and warming scans. Above 300K, compound 1 shows a SCO transition from the LS to the HS configuration although the transition is not fully achieved at 400K.

The applied perspectives of the <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> complexes are inherent to the potential of some pseudo-octahedral transition metal complexes to display a magnetic transition between the high spin (<ce:italic>HS</ce:italic>) and the low spin (<ce:italic>LS</ce:italic>) states through external stimuli such as temperature, pressure, magnetic field or light irradiation . The <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> phenomenon occurs in the d<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>–d<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup> transition metal complexes, but the most studied examples to date are those based on Fe(II) (d<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> configuration), for which a reversible paramagnetic–diamagnetic transition from the <ce:italic>HS</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>) to the <ce:italic>LS</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0, <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>) state is observed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal transition compounds exhibiting spin crossover (SCO) behavior have been widely investigated over the last decade and are still attracting intense research interest given their many potential applications in the development of novel electronic devices . The applied perspectives of the SCO complexes are inherent to the potential of some pseudo-octahedral transition metal complexes to display a magnetic transition between the high spin (HS) and the low spin (LS) states through external stimuli such as temperature, pressure, magnetic field or light irradiation . The SCO phenomenon occurs in the d4-d7 transition metal complexes, but the most studied examples to date are those based on Fe(II) (d6 configuration), for which a reversible paramagnetic-diamagnetic transition from the HS (S =2, 5T2g) to the LS (S =0, 1A1g) state is observed.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Up to now, numerous mononuclear compounds (mainly Fe(II) complexes) have been extensively studied . In such discrete systems, the intermolecular interactions (π-stacking, hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions), which generate the supramolecular architecture in the solid state, play a crucial role in the transmission of the magneto-elastic cooperative interactions at the origin of the hysteretic behavior. Unfortunately, their non covalent character precludes any control on the way they extend in the solid structure, and consequently on the <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> characteristics. In order to better explore the cooperative effect between the active metal sites, an alternative approach, based on the use of suitable bridging ligands to covalently connect the metal centers, has been introduced . This strategy has already resulted in the syntheses of several Fe(II) <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> coordination polymers exhibiting rich and fascinating structural features coupled to their magnetic behaviors. However, in contrast to the mononuclear compounds, these studies remain scarcely reported because of the limited number of potentially appropriate bridging ligands. In this context, we have extended this polymeric approach to the highly conjugated cyanocarbanion ligands involving several potentially donating nitrogen atoms juxtaposed in such a way that they cannot all coordinate to the same metal ion . We have recently reported a detailed photocrystallographic and photomagnetic study  on the first <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> iron(II) molecular neutral chain [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tcpd)] involving an anion as bridging ligand ((tcpd)<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(C[C(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-dicyanomethylene-1,1,3,3-tetracyanopropanediide anion; abpt<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-amino-3,5-bis(pyridin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole). Continuing our investigations on such <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> polymeric materials, we have extended this study to more rigid anionic bridging ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Up to now, numerous mononuclear compounds (mainly Fe(II) complexes) have been extensively studied . In such discrete systems, the intermolecular interactions (π-stacking, hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions), which generate the supramolecular architecture in the solid state, play a crucial role in the transmission of the magneto-elastic cooperative interactions at the origin of the hysteretic behavior. Unfortunately, their non covalent character precludes any control on the way they extend in the solid structure, and consequently on the SCO characteristics. In order to better explore the cooperative effect between the active metal sites, an alternative approach, based on the use of suitable bridging ligands to covalently connect the metal centers, has been introduced . This strategy has already resulted in the syntheses of several Fe(II) SCO coordination polymers exhibiting rich and fascinating structural features coupled to their magnetic behaviors. However, in contrast to the mononuclear compounds, these studies remain scarcely reported because of the limited number of potentially appropriate bridging ligands. In this context, we have extended this polymeric approach to the highly conjugated cyanocarbanion ligands involving several potentially donating nitrogen atoms juxtaposed in such a way that they cannot all coordinate to the same metal ion . We have recently reported a detailed photocrystallographic and photomagnetic study  on the first SCO iron(II) molecular neutral chain [Fe(abpt)2(tcpd)] involving an anion as bridging ligand ((tcpd)2- =(C[C(CN)2]3)2- =2-dicyanomethylene-1,1,3,3-tetracyanopropanediide anion; abpt=4-amino-3,5-bis(pyridin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole). Continuing our investigations on such SCO polymeric materials, we have extended this study to more rigid anionic bridging ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In this context, we have prepared two new <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> 1D-polymeric coordination compounds [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-M(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, with M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pt<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), where the tetracyanometallate planar anions [M(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> act as μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging ligands. The magnetic properties of a hemihydrated form of the Ni derivative (compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) have been reported very recently by Trávníček et al. , although the crystal structure was not reported. Therefore, here we will focus on the crystal structure characterizations of both compounds (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2)</ce:bold> and the magnetic properties of the Pt derivative (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this context, we have prepared two new SCO 1D-polymeric coordination compounds [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)]⋅xH2O, with M=PtII (1) and NiII (2), where the tetracyanometallate planar anions [M(CN)4]2- act as μ2-bridging ligands. The magnetic properties of a hemihydrated form of the Ni derivative (compound 2) have been reported very recently by Trávníček et al. , although the crystal structure was not reported. Therefore, here we will focus on the crystal structure characterizations of both compounds (1 and 2) and the magnetic properties of the Pt derivative (1).

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General remarks

All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. The starting materials and solvents were purchased from commercial sources (analytical reagent grade) and used without further purification.

Preparations

Syntheses of [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)] (M=PtII (1), NiII (2))

An ethanolic solution (10mL) of abpt (95.3mg, 0.4mmol) was added progressively, under continuous stirring, to 10mL of a 1:1 water/methanol solution containing Fe(BF4)2⋅6H2O (67.5mg, 0.2mmol) and the corresponding salt of K2[M(CN)4] (M=PtII (1): 75.5mg, 0.2mmol; M=NiII (2): 48.2mg, 0.2mmol). For both compounds 1 and 2, the resulting red-orange precipitate was filtered off, washed with water and ethanol and then dried. [Fe(abpt)2(Pt(CN)4)] (1). Yield: 130mg, 78%. Anal. Calc. for C28H20N16FePt: C, 40.4; H, 2.4; N, 26.9. Found: C, 40.2; H, 2.3; N, 27.1%. IR (cm-1): 3225(br), 3179(m), 3142(m), 3079(m), 3051(m), 3019(w), 2164(m), 2132(s), 1633(s), 1609(m), 1588(s), 1568(m), 1541(w), 1521(w), 1490(m), 1461(s), 1426(s), 1402(m), 1340(w), 1301(w), 1289(w), 1276(w), 1256(m), 1167(w), 1147(m), 1116(m), 1082(s), 1057(s), 1038(s), 997(m), 907(w), 894(w), 792(s), 782(s), 755(s), 744(s), 742 (s), 714(w), 693(s), 640(m), 614(m), 526(w), 509(m), 482(m), 451(m). [Fe(abpt)2(Ni(CN)4)] (2). Yield: 103.0mg, 74%. Anal. Calc. for C28H20N16FeNi: C, 48.4; H, 2.9; N, 32.2. Found: C, 47.8; H, 2.6; N, 32.7%. IR (cm-1): 3237(br), 3178(m), 3080(m), 3054(m), 3019(w), 2151(m), 2121(s), 2082(w), 1631(s), 1609(m), 1589(s), 1569(m), 1541(w), 1523(w), 1492(m), 1462(s), 1428(s), 1402(m), 1340(w), 1302(w), 1290(w), 1278(w), 1258(m), 1157(m), 1147(m), 1117(m), 1085(s), 1058(s), 1039(s), 998(m), 910(w), 895(w), 797(s), 784(s), 757(s), 745(s), 729 (w), 714(w), 694(s), 641(m), 615(m), 532(w), 493(w), 468(m), 455(m).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Single-crystals preparation of [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Single-crystals of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were synthesized using gel diffusion technique. The gel phase was obtained by addition of tetramethoxysilane (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) to an aqueous solution (9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 56.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) with stirring; the gel was formed from the resulting solution after a few hours. Then, 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of a 1:1 water/ethanol solution of FeSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 41.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) and abpt ligand (0.33<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 78.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) were carefully layered onto the gel. Single-crystals of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> suitable for X-ray analysis were formed within 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>weeks. The IR spectrum of the red single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> formed within the gel is identical to that observed for the red powder of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (see Section ). Attempts to prepare single crystals of nickel analogue (compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) led us to only polycrystalline powder for which the IR spectrum is similar to that described above for this compound (see Section ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single-crystals preparation of [Fe(abpt)2(μ-Pt(CN)4)] (1)

Single-crystals of compound 1 were synthesized using gel diffusion technique. The gel phase was obtained by addition of tetramethoxysilane (1mL) to an aqueous solution (9mL) of K2[Pt(CN)4)] (0.15mmol, 56.6mg) with stirring; the gel was formed from the resulting solution after a few hours. Then, 6mL of a 1:1 water/ethanol solution of FeSO4⋅7H2O (0.15mmol, 41.7mg) and abpt ligand (0.33mmol, 78.6mg) were carefully layered onto the gel. Single-crystals of compound 1 suitable for X-ray analysis were formed within 2weeks. The IR spectrum of the red single crystals of 1 formed within the gel is identical to that observed for the red powder of 1 (see Section ). Attempts to prepare single crystals of nickel analogue (compound 2) led us to only polycrystalline powder for which the IR spectrum is similar to that described above for this compound (see Section ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st035">X-ray structure studies of [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-M(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pt<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>))</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">A red single crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was placed at the top of a glass fibre with silicone grease and mounted on an Xcalibur 2 CCD Diffractometer (Oxford Diffraction) fitted with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Data were collected at 150 and 294<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses, and were refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by weighted anisotropic full-matrix least-square methods . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically while the hydrogen atoms were calculated and therefore included as isotropic fixed contributors to <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>. Data collection and data reduction were done with the CRYSALIS-CCD and CRYSALIS-RED programs . All other calculations were performed with standard procedures (WINGX) . Crystal data, structure refinement and collection parameters of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The polycrystalline powder of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Ni(II) analogue) allowed us to perform the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD). The room-temperature X-ray powder diffraction spectra (XRPD) were recorded on a PANalytical Empyrean X-ray powder diffractometer at 45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV, 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA with a Cu-target tube. For comparison purposes, XRPD was also carried out on polycrystalline powder of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The measured diffraction patterns were analyzed using the Rietveld method as implemented in the MAUD program . As a starting point, the diffraction pattern of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was simulated from the single crystal data. In a second step, only selected parameters were refined in the Rietveld procedure (cell parameters, mean crystallite size, and <ce:italic>r.m.s.</ce:italic> (root mean square) microstrain); the atomic positions and atomic displacement parameters were kept fixed at the single crystal value. The same procedure was applied for the diffraction pattern of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, using the single crystal structural data of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for the simulation, just changing the atom type Pt by Ni in the model. The aim of these two refinements was to infer the compatibility of the single crystal structure with the powder diffraction data whose resolution does not allow going further in the structural analysis through a complete Rietveld refinement.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure studies of [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)] (M=PtII (1), NiII (2))

A red single crystal of 1 was placed at the top of a glass fibre with silicone grease and mounted on an Xcalibur 2 CCD Diffractometer (Oxford Diffraction) fitted with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Data were collected at 150 and 294K. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses, and were refined on F 2 by weighted anisotropic full-matrix least-square methods . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically while the hydrogen atoms were calculated and therefore included as isotropic fixed contributors to F c. Data collection and data reduction were done with the CRYSALIS-CCD and CRYSALIS-RED programs . All other calculations were performed with standard procedures (WINGX) . Crystal data, structure refinement and collection parameters of 1 are listed in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in  . The polycrystalline powder of compound 2 (Ni(II) analogue) allowed us to perform the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD). The room-temperature X-ray powder diffraction spectra (XRPD) were recorded on a PANalytical Empyrean X-ray powder diffractometer at 45kV, 40mA with a Cu-target tube. For comparison purposes, XRPD was also carried out on polycrystalline powder of compound 1. The measured diffraction patterns were analyzed using the Rietveld method as implemented in the MAUD program . As a starting point, the diffraction pattern of 1 was simulated from the single crystal data. In a second step, only selected parameters were refined in the Rietveld procedure (cell parameters, mean crystallite size, and r.m.s. (root mean square) microstrain); the atomic positions and atomic displacement parameters were kept fixed at the single crystal value. The same procedure was applied for the diffraction pattern of 2, using the single crystal structural data of 1 for the simulation, just changing the atom type Pt by Ni in the model. The aim of these two refinements was to infer the compatibility of the single crystal structure with the powder diffraction data whose resolution does not allow going further in the structural analysis through a complete Rietveld refinement.

elements.clean_text:
Physical measurements

Infrared spectra were recorded in the range 4000-200cm-1 on a FT-IR BRUKER ATR VERTEX70 Spectrometer. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range 2-400K, cooling and warming the sample at 1K/min with an applied magnetic field of 0.5T on a polycrystalline sample of compound 1 (mass=8.90mg) with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holder previously measured under the same conditions, and for the diamagnetic contribution as deduced by using Pascal's constant tables (χ dia =-360.08×10-6 emumol-1). Elemental analyses were performed at the "Service de microanalyse", CNRS, 91198 Gif-sur-Yvette.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions

The IR spectrum of 1 shows sharp peaks attributed to the distinctive bond vibrations modes of the abpt ligand, i.e. (i) the ν (NH) absorption bands of the amino group in the 3250-3140cm-1 region, (ii) the stretching modes of the aromatic (CH) bonds detected in the 3080-3015cm-1 region and (iii) the stretching modes of the aromatic (CC) and (CN) bonds localized in the 1635-1500 and 1500-1400cm-1 regions, respectively . The modifications and the shifts of those bands, with respect to the IR spectrum of the abpt molecule only, clearly suggest the coordination of the abpt moiety in compound 1. Moreover, the two characteristic strong ν(CN) bands, observed at 2164 and 2132cm-1 and distinct from the stretching vibration modes observed in K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O, 1 Infrared data of K2[Pt(CN)4].xH2O (cm-1): 3628(br), 3543(br), 2135(s), 2121(s), 1906(w), 1615(s), 1397(w), 503(s), 468(w), 426(s).   can be respectively assigned to bridging and terminal CN groups, indirectly revealing the coordinated character of the [Pt(CN)4]2- moiety in compound 1.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is built from one Fe(II) cation, one [Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, both located on inversion centers, and one chelating abpt ligand located on a general position. As indicated above, despite several attempts to prepare single crystals of nickel analogue (compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) using different techniques such as slow evaporation, slow diffusion in H tube and gel diffusion technique, only polycrystalline powder has been prepared. In order to verify whether the Ni(II) and Pt(II) analogues are isostructural, the measured powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the two samples were analysed using the Rietveld method, and compared to the patterns simulated from the single crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, the diffraction pattern of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is well reproduced using the room temperature (294<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) single crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, with refined cell parameters (<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.480(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.039(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10.070(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>83.707(4)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>65.384(3)°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>88.968(4)°) close to the results of the single crystal analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 is built from one Fe(II) cation, one [Pt(CN)4]2- anion, both located on inversion centers, and one chelating abpt ligand located on a general position. As indicated above, despite several attempts to prepare single crystals of nickel analogue (compound 2) using different techniques such as slow evaporation, slow diffusion in H tube and gel diffusion technique, only polycrystalline powder has been prepared. In order to verify whether the Ni(II) and Pt(II) analogues are isostructural, the measured powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the two samples were analysed using the Rietveld method, and compared to the patterns simulated from the single crystal structure of 1. As shown in  , the diffraction pattern of 1 is well reproduced using the room temperature (294K) single crystal structure of 1, with refined cell parameters (a =8.480(1)Å, b =9.039(1)Å, c =10.070(1)Å, α =83.707(4)°, β =65.384(3)°, γ =88.968(4)°) close to the results of the single crystal analysis.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The microcrystalline powder of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a pure phase corresponding to the derived single crystal structure. The measured pattern of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is qualitatively similar to the pattern of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; with noticeable variations in diffraction peak intensity most probably due to the contrast in X-ray scattering power between Pt (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and Ni (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). The results of the Rietveld analysis indicate a small difference in refined unit cell parameters (<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.525(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.241(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.658(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>83.97(1)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>65.262(6)°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90.71(1)°) with respect to the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> cell parameter decreases by 0.412(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (4.1%), while the unit cell volume is reduced by 8.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (1.2%). The major differences in the diffraction pattern, such as the observed quasi splitting of several peaks (e.g. at 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.8°, 11.5°), result from the large decrease in the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> cell parameter from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Accounting for this adjustment in cell parameters, all the diffraction peaks in the measured pattern of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are satisfactorily reproduced with the pattern simulated from the single crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which suggest that the two compounds have very similar structures; the one dimensional topology is most probably preserved in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The microcrystalline powder of 1 is a pure phase corresponding to the derived single crystal structure. The measured pattern of 2 is qualitatively similar to the pattern of 1; with noticeable variations in diffraction peak intensity most probably due to the contrast in X-ray scattering power between Pt (for 1) and Ni (for 2). The results of the Rietveld analysis indicate a small difference in refined unit cell parameters (a =8.525(1)Å, b =9.241(1)Å, c =9.658(1)Å, α =83.97(1)°, β =65.262(6)°, γ =90.71(1)°) with respect to the structure of 1; the c cell parameter decreases by 0.412(1)Å (4.1%), while the unit cell volume is reduced by 8.6Å3 (1.2%). The major differences in the diffraction pattern, such as the observed quasi splitting of several peaks (e.g. at 2θ =9.8°, 11.5°), result from the large decrease in the c cell parameter from 1 to 2. Accounting for this adjustment in cell parameters, all the diffraction peaks in the measured pattern of 2 are satisfactorily reproduced with the pattern simulated from the single crystal structure of 1, which suggest that the two compounds have very similar structures; the one dimensional topology is most probably preserved in 2.

These observations are in good agreement with the value expected for the low spin (LS) state in the Fe(II) complexes displaying distorted octahedral geometry .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The crystal packing of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is formed by regular chains running along the crystallographic [−1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction where the planar [Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion acts as a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging ligand via two nitrogen atoms of two different <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> cyano groups (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Such linear chains are arranged in an eclipsed way along the [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0] direction, leading to the parallel structural arrangement depicted in . Along the neutral chains, the Fe⋯Pt distances are imposed by the cyano groups of the [Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> moiety (5.027 and 5.022<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 294 and 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively), leading to Fe⋯Fe intrachain distances of 10.055 and 10.045<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 294 and 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively, in agreement with the trans linear arrangement of the metal ions along the [−1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction. Albeit, the shortest Fe⋯Fe distances are simply defined by the length of the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (8.5046(3) and 8.4330(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 294 and 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The crystal packing of 1 is formed by regular chains running along the crystallographic [-101] direction where the planar [Pt(CN)4]2- anion acts as a μ2-bridging ligand via two nitrogen atoms of two different trans cyano groups ( ). Such linear chains are arranged in an eclipsed way along the [010] direction, leading to the parallel structural arrangement depicted in . Along the neutral chains, the Fe⋯Pt distances are imposed by the cyano groups of the [Pt(CN)4]2- moiety (5.027 and 5.022Å at 294 and 150K, respectively), leading to Fe⋯Fe intrachain distances of 10.055 and 10.045Å at 294 and 150K, respectively, in agreement with the trans linear arrangement of the metal ions along the [-101] direction. Albeit, the shortest Fe⋯Fe distances are simply defined by the length of the crystallographic a axis (8.5046(3) and 8.4330(3)Å at 294 and 150K, respectively).

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Careful examination of the crystal packing in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals the absence of any significant hydrogen bonding. However, moderate π-stacking interchain interactions through abpt–abpt interactions occur along the [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0] direction. Such abpt–abpt stacking, depicted in , is similar to those observed in the parent discrete complexes of the [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(A)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] series (A<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cyanocarbanion ligand<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>[C(C(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(X-R)]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (X-R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>O-Me, O-Et, O-Pr, O-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-OH, O-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH, O-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH(OH)CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and S-Me, tcm<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tricyanomethanide anion)  and in the related neutral chain [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tcpd)] ((tcpd)<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(C[C(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>) recently reported by us ; all of them presenting <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> transitions with transition temperatures in the range 100–380<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:para>

However, moderate π-stacking interchain interactions through abpt-abpt interactions occur along the [010] direction. Such abpt-abpt stacking, depicted in , is similar to those observed in the parent discrete complexes of the [Fe(abpt)2(A)2] series (A=cyanocarbanion ligand=[C(C(CN)2)2(X-R)]- (X-R=O-Me, O-Et, O-Pr, O-(CH2)2-OH, O-(CH2)3-OH, O-CH2CH(OH)CH3 and S-Me, tcm- =tricyanomethanide anion)  and in the related neutral chain [Fe(abpt)2(tcpd)] ((tcpd)2- =(C[C(CN)2]3)2-) recently reported by us ; all of them presenting SCO transitions with transition temperatures in the range 100-380K.

When the temperature is cooled from 400 to 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>

Indeed, only <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 65% of the Fe(II) ions are in the <ce:italic>HS</ce:italic> configuration at 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The corresponding transition temperature (<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>

<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> to reach a value of <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thermal dependence of the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility times the temperature (χ m T) for compound 1 shows a constant value close to 0.2emuKmol-1 in the temperature range 10-300K in the cooling and warming scans ( ). When the sample is heated above room temperature, χ m T increases to reach a value of ca. 2.1emuKmol-1 at 400K. When the temperature is cooled from 400 to 300K, the χ m T product shows no hysteretic behavior. The low χ m T value in the temperature range 10-300K indicates that the Fe(II) ion in compound 1 is in the low spin (LS) configuration, except for a small fraction of ca. 6% that is present in the high spin (HS) configuration. Above 300K, compound 1 shows a SCO from the LS to the HS configuration, although the transition is not fully achieved at 400K. Indeed, only ca. 65% of the Fe(II) ions are in the HS configuration at 400K. The corresponding transition temperature (T 1/2) of 382K, defined as the temperature when 50% of the Fe(II) ions are in the HS configuration, is similar to the temperature of the maximum slope of the χ m T plot (ca. 380K). At very low temperatures, the small fraction of HS Fe(II) ions shows the expected zero field splitting leading to a sharp decrease of χ m T to reach a value of ca. 0.05emuKmol-1 at 2K.

<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">A careful study of the intermolecular π-stacking performed in all the known Fe-abpt based compounds formulated as [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tcpd)] (tcpd<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>C[C(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>) and [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(A)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] with A<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tcm<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (tricyanomethanide anion), NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, NCSe<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, tcnq<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (tetracyanoquinodimethane) and [C(C(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(X-R)]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (X-R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>O-Me, O-Et, O-Pr, O-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-OH, O-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH, O-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH(OH)CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and S-Me)  has established that only the complexes displaying a frontal π-stacking of the abpt ligands of neighboring molecules tend to present a spin transition, while those involving a sideways π-stacking remain in the <ce:italic>HS</ce:italic> state (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>) . Thus, the configuration of the intermolecular abpt–abpt π stacking interactions appears as the crucial parameter concerning the occurrence of the <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> behavior in this system.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A careful study of the intermolecular π-stacking performed in all the known Fe-abpt based compounds formulated as [Fe(abpt)2(tcpd)] (tcpd=C[C(CN)2]3 2-) and [Fe(abpt)2(A)2] with A=tcm- (tricyanomethanide anion), NCS-, NCSe-, tcnq- (tetracyanoquinodimethane) and [C(C(CN)2)2(X-R)]- (X-R=O-Me, O-Et, O-Pr, O-(CH2)2-OH, O-(CH2)3-OH, O-CH2CH(OH)CH3 and S-Me)  has established that only the complexes displaying a frontal π-stacking of the abpt ligands of neighboring molecules tend to present a spin transition, while those involving a sideways π-stacking remain in the HS state (see  ) . Thus, the configuration of the intermolecular abpt-abpt π stacking interactions appears as the crucial parameter concerning the occurrence of the SCO behavior in this system.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The frontal π-stacking type observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (), similar to that observed for other Fe-abpt series exhibiting a <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> behavior , is in good agreement with the magnetic behavior described above. However, the crystallographic data reveal weaker π–π interactions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> since the abpt–abpt intermolecular contacts (C–C, C–N and N–N contacts in the range 3.4–3.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) are significantly longer than those observed for the parent Fe-abpt <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> derivatives (shorter C–C, C–N and N–N contacts in the range 3.3–3.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . This difference can be explained by steric effects imposed by the rigidity of the inorganic bridging [Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion through the two uncoordinated cyano groups.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The frontal π-stacking type observed in 1 (), similar to that observed for other Fe-abpt series exhibiting a SCO behavior , is in good agreement with the magnetic behavior described above. However, the crystallographic data reveal weaker π-π interactions in 1 since the abpt-abpt intermolecular contacts (C-C, C-N and N-N contacts in the range 3.4-3.9Å) are significantly longer than those observed for the parent Fe-abpt SCO derivatives (shorter C-C, C-N and N-N contacts in the range 3.3-3.6Å) . This difference can be explained by steric effects imposed by the rigidity of the inorganic bridging [Pt(CN)4]2- anion through the two uncoordinated cyano groups.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st050">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Using single and powder X-ray diffraction, we have structurally characterized the first two examples of one dimensional neutral chain involving tetracyanometallate bridging ligands, [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-M(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pt<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)). As observed previously for the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> analogue (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) , compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> transition above room temperature, making difficult to reach any structural and electronic information on the <ce:italic>HS</ce:italic> state. Thus, in order to better control the transition temperature in such <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> systems involving inorganic planar anions and decrease it below room temperature, we are now using other chelating ligands displaying lower crystal field energies, such as 2-amino-pyridine or 8-aminoquinoline, that should lead to new spin-crossover systems exhibiting lower transition temperatures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Using single and powder X-ray diffraction, we have structurally characterized the first two examples of one dimensional neutral chain involving tetracyanometallate bridging ligands, [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)] (M=PtII (1), NiII (2)). As observed previously for the NiII analogue (2) , compound 1 displays a SCO transition above room temperature, making difficult to reach any structural and electronic information on the HS state. Thus, in order to better control the transition temperature in such SCO systems involving inorganic planar anions and decrease it below room temperature, we are now using other chelating ligands displaying lower crystal field energies, such as 2-amino-pyridine or 8-aminoquinoline, that should lead to new spin-crossover systems exhibiting lower transition temperatures.

Experimental

General remarks

All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. The starting materials and solvents were purchased from commercial sources (analytical reagent grade) and used without further purification.

Preparations

Syntheses of [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)] (M=PtII (1), NiII (2))

An ethanolic solution (10mL) of abpt (95.3mg, 0.4mmol) was added progressively, under continuous stirring, to 10mL of a 1:1 water/methanol solution containing Fe(BF4)2⋅6H2O (67.5mg, 0.2mmol) and the corresponding salt of K2[M(CN)4] (M=PtII (1): 75.5mg, 0.2mmol; M=NiII (2): 48.2mg, 0.2mmol). For both compounds 1 and 2, the resulting red-orange precipitate was filtered off, washed with water and ethanol and then dried. [Fe(abpt)2(Pt(CN)4)] (1). Yield: 130mg, 78%. Anal. Calc. for C28H20N16FePt: C, 40.4; H, 2.4; N, 26.9. Found: C, 40.2; H, 2.3; N, 27.1%. IR (cm-1): 3225(br), 3179(m), 3142(m), 3079(m), 3051(m), 3019(w), 2164(m), 2132(s), 1633(s), 1609(m), 1588(s), 1568(m), 1541(w), 1521(w), 1490(m), 1461(s), 1426(s), 1402(m), 1340(w), 1301(w), 1289(w), 1276(w), 1256(m), 1167(w), 1147(m), 1116(m), 1082(s), 1057(s), 1038(s), 997(m), 907(w), 894(w), 792(s), 782(s), 755(s), 744(s), 742 (s), 714(w), 693(s), 640(m), 614(m), 526(w), 509(m), 482(m), 451(m). [Fe(abpt)2(Ni(CN)4)] (2). Yield: 103.0mg, 74%. Anal. Calc. for C28H20N16FeNi: C, 48.4; H, 2.9; N, 32.2. Found: C, 47.8; H, 2.6; N, 32.7%. IR (cm-1): 3237(br), 3178(m), 3080(m), 3054(m), 3019(w), 2151(m), 2121(s), 2082(w), 1631(s), 1609(m), 1589(s), 1569(m), 1541(w), 1523(w), 1492(m), 1462(s), 1428(s), 1402(m), 1340(w), 1302(w), 1290(w), 1278(w), 1258(m), 1157(m), 1147(m), 1117(m), 1085(s), 1058(s), 1039(s), 998(m), 910(w), 895(w), 797(s), 784(s), 757(s), 745(s), 729 (w), 714(w), 694(s), 641(m), 615(m), 532(w), 493(w), 468(m), 455(m).

Single-crystals preparation of [Fe(abpt)2(μ-Pt(CN)4)] (1)

Single-crystals of compound 1 were synthesized using gel diffusion technique. The gel phase was obtained by addition of tetramethoxysilane (1mL) to an aqueous solution (9mL) of K2[Pt(CN)4)] (0.15mmol, 56.6mg) with stirring; the gel was formed from the resulting solution after a few hours. Then, 6mL of a 1:1 water/ethanol solution of FeSO4⋅7H2O (0.15mmol, 41.7mg) and abpt ligand (0.33mmol, 78.6mg) were carefully layered onto the gel. Single-crystals of compound 1 suitable for X-ray analysis were formed within 2weeks. The IR spectrum of the red single crystals of 1 formed within the gel is identical to that observed for the red powder of 1 (see Section ). Attempts to prepare single crystals of nickel analogue (compound 2) led us to only polycrystalline powder for which the IR spectrum is similar to that described above for this compound (see Section ).

<ce:section-title id="st065">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">New iron(II) coordination polymeric neutral chain of formula [Fe(abpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-M(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)], with M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pt<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and abpt<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-amino-3,5-bis(pyridin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole, have been synthesized and characterized by infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. The two compounds are isostructural as deduced from a Rietveld analysis of X-ray powder diffraction data of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> simulated from the single crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The crystal packing of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is formed by regular chains running along the crystallographic [−1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction where the planar [Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion acts as a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging ligand via two nitrogen atoms of two different <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> cyano groups, while the two abpt molecules act as chelating ligands. Along the neutral chains, the Fe⋯Pt distances are imposed by the cyano groups of the [Pt(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> moiety (5.027 and 5.022<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 294 and 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively), leading to Fe⋯Fe intrachain distances of 10.055 and 10.045<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 294 and 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. The thermal dependence of the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility times the temperature (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>) for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a constant value close to 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in the temperature range 10–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K in the cooling and warming scans. Above 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a <ce:italic>SCO</ce:italic> transition from the <ce:italic>LS</ce:italic> to the <ce:italic>HS</ce:italic> configuration although the transition is not fully achieved at 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st040">Physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Infrared spectra were recorded in the range 4000–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on a FT-IR BRUKER ATR VERTEX70 Spectrometer. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range 2–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, cooling and warming the sample at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K/min with an applied magnetic field of 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T on a polycrystalline sample of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (mass<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holder previously measured under the same conditions, and for the diamagnetic contribution as deduced by using Pascal’s constant tables (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">dia</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−360.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−6</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). Elemental analyses were performed at the “Service de microanalyse”, CNRS, 91198 Gif-sur-Yvette.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st045">Results and discussions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows sharp peaks attributed to the distinctive bond vibrations modes of the abpt ligand, i.e. (i) the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">(NH)</ce:inf> absorption bands of the amino group in the 3250-3140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region, (ii) the stretching modes of the aromatic (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>H) bonds detected in the 3080–3015<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region and (iii) the stretching modes of the aromatic (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C) and (C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N) bonds localized in the 1635–1500 and 1500–1400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> regions, respectively . The modifications and the shifts of those bands, with respect to the IR spectrum of the abpt molecule only, clearly suggest the coordination of the abpt moiety in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

New iron(II) coordination polymeric neutral chain of formula [Fe(abpt)2(μ-M(CN)4)], with M=PtII (1), NiII (2) and abpt=4-amino-3,5-bis(pyridin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole, have been synthesized and characterized by infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. The two compounds are isostructural as deduced from a Rietveld analysis of X-ray powder diffraction data of 2 simulated from the single crystal structure of 1. The crystal packing of 1 is formed by regular chains running along the crystallographic [-101] direction where the planar [Pt(CN)4]2- anion acts as a μ2-bridging ligand via two nitrogen atoms of two different trans cyano groups, while the two abpt molecules act as chelating ligands. Along the neutral chains, the Fe⋯Pt distances are imposed by the cyano groups of the [Pt(CN)4]2- moiety (5.027 and 5.022Å at 294 and 150K, respectively), leading to Fe⋯Fe intrachain distances of 10.055 and 10.045Å at 294 and 150K, respectively. The thermal dependence of the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility times the temperature (χ m T) for compound 1 shows a constant value close to 0.2emuKmol-1 in the temperature range 10-300K in the cooling and warming scans. Above 300K, compound 1 shows a SCO transition from the LS to the HS configuration although the transition is not fully achieved at 400K.

Physical measurements

Infrared spectra were recorded in the range 4000-200cm-1 on a FT-IR BRUKER ATR VERTEX70 Spectrometer. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range 2-400K, cooling and warming the sample at 1K/min with an applied magnetic field of 0.5T on a polycrystalline sample of compound 1 (mass=8.90mg) with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holder previously measured under the same conditions, and for the diamagnetic contribution as deduced by using Pascal's constant tables (χ dia =-360.08×10-6 emumol-1). Elemental analyses were performed at the "Service de microanalyse", CNRS, 91198 Gif-sur-Yvette.

Results and discussions

The IR spectrum of 1 shows sharp peaks attributed to the distinctive bond vibrations modes of the abpt ligand, i.e. (i) the ν (NH) absorption bands of the amino group in the 3250-3140cm-1 region, (ii) the stretching modes of the aromatic (CH) bonds detected in the 3080-3015cm-1 region and (iii) the stretching modes of the aromatic (CC) and (CN) bonds localized in the 1635-1500 and 1500-1400cm-1 regions, respectively . The modifications and the shifts of those bands, with respect to the IR spectrum of the abpt molecule only, clearly suggest the coordination of the abpt moiety in compound 1. Moreover, the two characteristic strong ν(CN) bands, observed at 2164 and 2132cm-1 and distinct from the stretching vibration modes observed in K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O, 1 Infrared data of K2[Pt(CN)4].xH2O (cm-1): 3628(br), 3543(br), 2135(s), 2121(s), 1906(w), 1615(s), 1397(w), 503(s), 468(w), 426(s).   can be respectively assigned to bridging and terminal CN groups, indirectly revealing the coordinated character of the [Pt(CN)4]2- moiety in compound 1.

The structure of 1 is built from one Fe(II) cation, one [Pt(CN)4]2- anion, both located on inversion centers, and one chelating abpt ligand located on a general position. As indicated above, despite several attempts to prepare single crystals of nickel analogue (compound 2) using different techniques such as slow evaporation, slow diffusion in H tube and gel diffusion technique, only polycrystalline powder has been prepared. In order to verify whether the Ni(II) and Pt(II) analogues are isostructural, the measured powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the two samples were analysed using the Rietveld method, and compared to the patterns simulated from the single crystal structure of 1. As shown in  , the diffraction pattern of 1 is well reproduced using the room temperature (294K) single crystal structure of 1, with refined cell parameters (a =8.480(1)Å, b =9.039(1)Å, c =10.070(1)Å, α =83.707(4)°, β =65.384(3)°, γ =88.968(4)°) close to the results of the single crystal analysis.

The microcrystalline powder of 1 is a pure phase corresponding to the derived single crystal structure. The measured pattern of 2 is qualitatively similar to the pattern of 1; with noticeable variations in diffraction peak intensity most probably due to the contrast in X-ray scattering power between Pt (for 1) and Ni (for 2). The results of the Rietveld analysis indicate a small difference in refined unit cell parameters (a =8.525(1)Å, b =9.241(1)Å, c =9.658(1)Å, α =83.97(1)°, β =65.262(6)°, γ =90.71(1)°) with respect to the structure of 1; the c cell parameter decreases by 0.412(1)Å (4.1%), while the unit cell volume is reduced by 8.6Å3 (1.2%). The major differences in the diffraction pattern, such as the observed quasi splitting of several peaks (e.g. at 2θ =9.8°, 11.5°), result from the large decrease in the c cell parameter from 1 to 2. Accounting for this adjustment in cell parameters, all the diffraction peaks in the measured pattern of 2 are satisfactorily reproduced with the pattern simulated from the single crystal structure of 1, which suggest that the two compounds have very similar structures; the one dimensional topology is most probably preserved in 2.

The average values of the six Fe-N distances observed at 150K and at room temperature (294K) are 1.982(4) and 1.987(5)Å, respectively. These observations are in good agreement with the value expected for the low spin (LS) state in the Fe(II) complexes displaying distorted octahedral geometry .

The crystal packing of 1 is formed by regular chains running along the crystallographic [-101] direction where the planar [Pt(CN)4]2- anion acts as a μ2-bridging ligand via two nitrogen atoms of two different trans cyano groups ( ). Such linear chains are arranged in an eclipsed way along the [010] direction, leading to the parallel structural arrangement depicted in . Along the neutral chains, the Fe⋯Pt distances are imposed by the cyano groups of the [Pt(CN)4]2- moiety (5.027 and 5.022Å at 294 and 150K, respectively), leading to Fe⋯Fe intrachain distances of 10.055 and 10.045Å at 294 and 150K, respectively, in agreement with the trans linear arrangement of the metal ions along the [-101] direction. Albeit, the shortest Fe⋯Fe distances are simply defined by the length of the crystallographic a axis (8.5046(3) and 8.4330(3)Å at 294 and 150K, respectively).

cln_elements.clean_text: The thermal dependence of the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility times the temperature (χ m T) for compound 1 shows a constant value close to 0.2emuKmol-1 in the temperature range 10-300K in the cooling and warming scans ( ). When the sample is heated above room temperature, χ m T increases to reach a value of ca. 2.1emuKmol-1 at 400K. When the temperature is cooled from 400 to 300K, the χ m T product shows no hysteretic behavior. The low χ m T value in the temperature range 10-300K indicates that the Fe(II) ion in compound 1 is in the low spin (LS) configuration, except for a small fraction of ca. 6% that is present in the high spin (HS) configuration. Above 300K, compound 1 shows a SCO from the LS to the HS configuration, although the transition is not fully achieved at 400K. Indeed, only ca. 65% of the Fe(II) ions are in the HS configuration at 400K. The corresponding transition temperature (T 1/2) of 382K, defined as the temperature when 50% of the Fe(II) ions are in the HS configuration, is similar to the temperature of the maximum slope of the χ m T plot (ca. 380K). At very low temperatures, the small fraction of HS Fe(II) ions shows the expected zero field splitting leading to a sharp decrease of χ m T to reach a value of ca. 0.05emuKmol-1 at 2K.
